an7.56:4.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, on the Vulture’s Peak Mountain.
an7.56:4.3: Then, late at night, a beautiful god, lighting up the entire Vulture’s Peak, went up to the Buddha,
an7.56:4.7: And another god told the Buddha:
an7.56:4.8: “Sir, these nuns are well freed without anything left over!”
an7.56:4.9: This is what that god said,
an7.56:4.11: Then that god, knowing that the teacher approved, bowed and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on his right, before vanishing right there.
an7.56:5.1: Then, when the night had passed, the Buddha told the mendicants all that had happened.
an7.56:6.1: Now, at that time Venerable Mahāmoggallāna was sitting not far from the Buddha.
an7.56:6.3: “Which gods know whether a person has anything left over or not?”
an7.56:6.5: Now, at that time a monk called Tissa had recently passed away and been reborn in a Brahmā realm.
an7.56:6.7: Tissa the Brahmā was very mighty and powerful.
an7.56:7.2: as easily as a strong person would extend or contract their arm,

an7.56:7.11: Moggallāna sat down on the indicated seat.
an7.56:7.12: Then Tissa bowed to Moggallāna and sat to one side.
an7.56:7.14: “Which gods know whether a person has anything left over or not?”
an7.56:7.16: “The gods in the company of Brahmā know this.”
an7.56:8.1: “But do all of them know this?”
an7.56:8.3: “No, my good Moggallāna, not all of them.
an7.56:9.1: Those gods in the company of Brahmā who are content with the lifespan of Brahmā, with the beauty, happiness, fame, and authority of Brahmā, and who don’t truly understand any higher escape:
an7.56:9.4: But those gods in the company of Brahmā who are not content with the lifespan of Brahmā, with the beauty, happiness, fame, and authority of Brahmā, and who do truly understand a higher escape:
an7.56:10.1: Take a mendicant who is freed both ways.
an7.56:10.4: As long as their body remains they will be seen by gods and humans.
an7.56:10.5: But when their body breaks up gods and men will see them no more.’
an7.56:10.6: This too is how those gods know whether a person has anything left over or not.
an7.56:11.1: Take a mendicant who is freed by wisdom.
an7.56:11.4: As long as their body remains they will be seen by gods and humans.
an7.56:11.5: But when their body breaks up gods and men will see them no more.’
an7.56:11.6: This too is how those gods know whether a person has anything left over or not.
an7.56:12.1: Take a mendicant who is a direct witness.

an7.56:12.5: Then they might realize the supreme culmination of the spiritual path in this very life, and live having achieved with their own insight the goal for which people from good families rightly go forth from the lay life to homelessness.’
an7.56:12.7: This too is how those gods know whether a person has anything left over or not.

an7.56:15.1: “But Moggallāna, Tissa the Brahmā didn’t teach the seventh person, the signless meditator.”
an7.56:15.2: “Now is the time, Blessed One! Now is the time, Holy One!
an7.56:15.3: May the Buddha teach the seventh person, the signless meditator.
an7.56:15.4: The mendicants will listen and remember it.”
an7.56:15.5: “Well then, Moggallāna, listen and pay close attention,
an7.56:16.1: “Moggallāna, take the case of a mendicant who, not focusing on any signs, enters and remains in the signless samādhi of the heart.
an7.56:16.3: ‘This venerable, not focusing on any signs, enters and remains in the signless samādhi of the heart.
an7.56:16.4: Hopefully this venerable will frequent appropriate lodgings, associate with good friends, and guide their faculties.
an7.56:16.5: Then they might realize the supreme culmination of the spiritual path in this very life, and live having achieved with their own insight the goal for which people from good families rightly go forth from the lay life to homelessness.’
an7.56:16.7: This too is how those gods know whether a person has anything left over or not.”
